awd_titl_txt: Engaging Women in Engineering: Training Mentors to Make a Difference
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will advance efforts of the Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program by preparing high-achieving high school students for advanced science and math courses and eventually courses in engineering. ITEST seeks to better understand and promote practices that increase students' motivations and capacities to pursue careers in fields of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM). To be globally competitive, the US must optimize the available workforce to include women in STEM. There are two fundamental issues that need to be addressed in engaging women in engineering: motivation and preparedness to pursue STEM careers. The Academy of Natural Sciences will partner with Drexel University: College of Engineering and School of Education, and local engineering professionals, through the Engineering WINS (EngWINS) program. EngWINS will develop the capabilities of working engineers and faculty to serve as mentors in a new initiative to develop interest, self-efficacy, and persistence in engineering careers among urban high school women. The project's immediate impacts extend from an out-of-school learning environment and into urban academic and industrial research centers. The workforce development would be fueled by: 1) diversifying the STEM pipeline, 2) supporting the advancement of all women in STEM fields, and 3) studying the impacts of EngWINS training among adult mentors. The project findings will have relevance for human resource practices in higher education and industry and will be disseminated among educators in engineering in both academic and out of school settings. 

Project research will investigate how and to what extent a largely homogeneous group of working engineers can enter mentoring relationships that increase participation in their field by underrepresented populations. The project goals, scope, methods, and approaches will address the following questions: To what extent does training in culturally responsive pedagogies and anti-discriminatory frameworks shift adult mentors, mindsets, and dispositions toward their work with EngWINS students, as well as in other teaching contexts or workplace interactions with women and minorities?  To what extent do pairings of mentors and mentees from different backgrounds influence students' interest, self-efficacy, and persistence in engineering education and careers? To what extent does interest, self-efficacy, and persistence in engineering differ between EngWINS students who have a mentor versus. those who only experience the regular EngWINS curriculum?  The projects will use mixed-methods and quasi-experimental design. There will be multiple data sources such as classroom observations, interviews, and surveys/assessments to measure student and mentor outcomes. The project will enroll adult mentor candidates into a full year of professional development training in culturally relevant pedagogies, ways to combat stereotype barriers, and implicit biases, prior to entering mentoring relationships.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: ACADEMY OF NATURAL SCIENCES OF PHILADELPHIA

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: The Academy of Natural Sciences of Drexel University

por.por_cntn:
Drexel University’s Academy of Natural Sciences, School of Education and College of Engineering in partnership with Philadelphia Education Fund and Hillary Blecker Consulting created and implemented a new engineering program within an established natural science out-of-school time program for minoritized, urban high school women. Through EngWINS (Engaging Women in Engineering: Training Mentors to Make a Difference) the team developed curriculum and a mentor training program to help develop the capabilities of working engineers and faculty to better serve as mentors helping female high school students to develop interest, self-efficacy, and persistence in engineering.

What we did

The team developed 30 new engineering infused lessons that introduced design thinking, engineering tools, knowledge and skills and engineering careers into the natural science program. 113 students piloted these new lessons and helped the team improve them year over year. The team created a EngWINS Playbook that contains these lessons and best practices for developing Out-of-School time programs. EngWINS also trained 40 engineering mentors who support 42 students in paid engineering internships.

What we learned

About Mentors (See Figure 1) - Mentors tended to develop two distinct mentoring approaches. One group thought developing a personal relationship with their mentee was important while the other group thought creating a distance and professional atmosphere would better prepare mentees for the “realities” of STEM environments.

Some mentors embraced training. Most mentors shared how they embraced the trainings and several suggested that the trainings encouraged them to shift their perspectives about working with minoritized women. The training invited the mentors to acknowledge their own privileges and biases; Matt shared, “those of us who are white middle-aged straight men, we've never had to think about this stuff before because we're kind of the default”. The mentors reported that the opportunity to hear specific examples from other members of the mentor group about how they experienced racism and sexism in STEM were particularly impactful. Monique, who is herself a Black woman in science, said that the training opened a new perspective for her as well. She shared, “I've seen people interact that way with me and now I understand a little bit better why. It's because of their biases [and it’s] not necessarily about me”.   

Mentors who took a relational approach to mentoring were more likely to report embracing the training, whereas mentors who ascribed to a more distanced mentoring approach were more likely to challenge the training (Figure 1). The use of CRF as a lens invites us to recognize complexity in mentorship relationships involving young WOC in STEM (Nkrumah & Scott, 2022). The results of this study suggest that mentors’ intersectional identities and their own trajectories within the STEM field may influence their dispositions towards mentoring young WOC.

About Students in EngWINS– The program creates three inter-related working ecosystems for students (see Figure 2). Many students expressed that their experiences in the EngWINS program expanded their understanding of the STEM career landscape. Mae shared that prior to participating in the program she had only really considered law as a potential career path, but EngWINS showed her that there is a wide variety in the types of engineering possible to pursue: “After EWIS I realized that there were a lot of fields in engineering and what we focused on was how engineering connected to nature… So, I guess the variety in engineering kind of made it a new career path for me. A possible career path”. 

Not only did students’ awareness of available STEM career paths increase, but also their visions for themselves became more specific and higher-ranking. When asked how her experience in the EWIS program has influenced what career she wants to pursue, Kadijah explained how the program helped her develop a deeper understanding of what an engineer does and while she does not want to pursue the engineering path, she shared that the experience has helped her to “step up the career I want to do”.

How we share our learning

  1. The EngWINS Playbook allows the team to share best practices from this research to practice project with other Out-of-School time programs.
  2. The team continues to develop and refine its mentor training sharing the training with universities, industry partners and others helping them to launch culturally responsive and supportive mentoring programs.
  3. The team has presented and continues to present at professional conferences such as American Educational Research Association, National STEM Teachers Association and Association of Science and Technology Centers.
  4. Publications- Stepping out and stepping up: Narratives of women of color in an urban STEM OST program in the Journal of Urban Learning, Teaching, and Research and   “What we really need”: How the women in natural sciences (WINS) program supports culturally sustaining mentorship and STEM career opportunities for women of color. in Mentoring through a female STEM identity lens: Heroes make a difference for women in STEM.

Last Modified: 01/24/2024
Modified by: Jacqueline Genovesi
